All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. objectives

This mechanism will strategically scale-up and expand quality CHTC and linkage to care for high-risk, undiagnosed HIV positives and to provide comprehensive support for KP activities to include test and treat and PrEP. Identifying people living with HIV (PLHIV) and linking them to treatment and care is the essential first step in the cascade to achieving UNAID’s 90-90-90 goals and epidemic control in Botswana. Testing funded through this award will use a combination of modalities including HCT at high yield standalone testing sites and targeted community-based approaches including targeted home based testing and self-testing. The goal of the expanded CHTC activities is to identify HIV-positive individuals including KP, and link them to care and treatment facilities and community support for PLHIV. HIV-negative clients will receive systematic referrals to appropriate prevention interventions such as voluntary medical male circumcision services for males 15 years and older and partner services/disclosure assistance. Condoms will be provided to all clients and appropriate gender messaging will be integrated into counseling. CHTC will be conducted in priority community locations and will target under-accessed populations such as construction workers, men, adolescent girls and young women and key populations (including MSM and FSW). The program will be conducted in eight health districts: Mahalapye, Southern, South East, Kgatleng, Goodhope, Gaborone, Chobe and Kweneng East. These districts may change based on new data and evolving PEPFAR and Government of Botswana (GOB) priorities. As the PEPFAR lead for strategic and expanded CHCT, referral and linkages to care and treatment, the TBD partner will work closely with the GOB and other PEPFAR implementing partners.
